awd_titl_txt: Systematic Modulation of Lanthanide Physical Properties Using Functionalized Metallacrowns
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Vincent L. Pecoraro of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor is developing a class of metallamacrocycles containing lanthanide ions.  The goal of this research is to understand the electronic properties of lanthanide ions that are critical to a vast range of modern technologies such as magnetic materials, white light displays, and luminescent imaging in biological systems. In addition, these studies seek to develop the foundation to make new molecular nanothermometers that can be used over a wide temperature range for applications in both the electronics industry as well as in basic biological research or eventually clinically to measure temperatures within cell organelles or animal tissue. The project lies at the interface of organic, inorganic, materials chemistry and biological chemistry. The research is well suited for the education of scientists at all levels.  Through general interest presentation, outreach to the lay public is also planned. An example is that Professor Pecoraro will give public lectures related to his research both in the United States and Europe.  Professor Pecoraro has a history of supporting the education and training for students underrepresented in science and these activities will continue.    

Lanthanide containing metallacrowns can be exploited to understand the fundamental properties of lanthanides. Because these ions contain electrons in their f-orbitals, which are contracted within the d-orbitals, they have interesting properties related to molecular magnetism, magnetocoolants and luminescent emission. In this project, metallacrowns will be prepared to answer the following questions: (i) How does the molecular symmetry and coordination number influence the electronic structure of lanthanides that are highly emitting or display single ion slow magnetic relaxation? (ii) Can metallacrowns be used as emitting cores for the class of polymers known as dendrimers, which are being applied for a variety of advanced applications in chemistry and biology; and (iii) Can one use magnetic fields to interrogate the excited ground states of lanthanides to understand, and calculate, the extent of ground state mixing to these excited states?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes from NSF CHE 2102046: Systematic Modulation of Lanthanide Physical Properties using Functionalized Metallacrowns have been both productive and enriching. During this grant, 2 papers and a book chapter have been published. Significant results that deepen knowledge in the fields of lanthanide (Ln) based nanothermometry and molecular magnetism have been achieved.

For the lanthanide based nanothermometry, new metallacrowns (MC) were prepared to improve the existing system based on the Tb3+ and Sm3+ lanthanide couple. By using different ligands to form these metallacrowns, the accessible temperature range was greatly improved. In these systems, the emitted light can be modulated by temperature change. By choosing appropriate metallacrown based nanothermometers, sub-micron temperature reading could be used in fields such as cellular imaging or microelectronics.

Two series of paramagnetic LnGa4 and LnGa8 metallacrowns (Ln = Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb) were studied by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR). NMR data were analyzed to establish the extend of the structural changes that occur from the solid state to the solution. Despite LnGa4 metallacrowns being isostructural in the solid state, it was found that the benzoates ligands displayed preferential orientation depending on the lanthanide considered, lowering the overall symmetry of the complex. NMR data of the LnGa8 metallacrown series are currently being analyzed for similar effects.

A Gd2Ga8 metallacrown could be doped by recrystallization in an isostructural inert matrix of Y2Ga8 without scrambling (i.e., generation of the YGdGa8 product), which is exceedingly rare, owing to the chemical similarity of the Ln3+ ions and solution phase scrambling that is common during molecular crystallization. The use of discrete magnetic molecules that can be doped, formed into arrays as desired, and have tunable interaction is extremely relevant toward a quantum information-based future. Crystals of doped Gd2Ga8 metallacrowns are currently being investigated to see if, and how the fundamental quantum states interact with one another.

During this grant one PhD student graduated, a postdoc was trained, and undergraduates were trained in synthetic chemistry in our laboratory. The metallacrowns were used in Chem 303 (Introductory Bioinorganic Chemistry) to teach about metal-based imaging agents, and in Chem 402 (senior level Inorganic Chemistry) to discuss supramolecular chemistry, molecular magnetism, luminescence, and the electronic structure of the lanthanides. This project also involved a significant amount of international collaboration with research groups based in France, Portugal, and Italy. The collaboration has not been restricted to international laboratories but was also conducted in the United States (FL, IN).


Last Modified: 08/25/2023
Modified by: Vincent L Pecoraro
